items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Further rain is expected throughout the night, which will keep the levels high, but we are not expecting to see any significant changes.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 28/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest this evening at 08:15 PM on 27/09/2023.
Flooding is possible at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon from 07:00 PM until 9:00 PM on 27/09/2023. with the local tide level forecast to reach 1.23m.
The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water at Padstow is at 4.43pm, flooding is possible 1 hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Storm Agnes is forecast to bring strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m which could cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be up to 550mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
The communities most at risk include Port Quin, Port Isaac, Port Gaverne, and Boscastle.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care near the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this information by midday on Thursday.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 4.76 mAOD, this is 0.55 metres above astronomical tide level.
Further flood alerts and warnings are expected to be issued this weekend associated with the largest astronomical tides of the year.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Chapel Porth to The Rumps excluding the tidal River Camel
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. 

High water at Padstow is at 4.43pm, flooding is possible one hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.

Storm Agnes is forecast to bring strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m which could cause wave overtopping and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be up to 550mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.

The communities most at risk include Trevaunance Cove, Perranporth, Newquay, Mawgan Porth, Trevone and Polzeath.

People are advised to take care near the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this information by midday on Thursday.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 4.76 mAOD, this is 0.55 metres above astronomical tide level.

Further flood alerts and warnings are expected to be issued this weekend associated with the largest astronomical tides of the year.

As a result of strong winds and spring tides, tides will be high and may cause flooding over the following 6 days.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddlerâ€™s Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge peaking tonight between at 22:30 and 23.15 at between 6.2m to 6.4m. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. This situation is likely to repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 2nd October, with spring tides coinciding with spring tides.  There are two high tides a day, with the night tides being higher than the day time high tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight on 27/09/2023 at 10:00PM.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large offshore waves.
With high spring tides, this situation is likely to be repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 2nd October. 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 28/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 5.25pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 7, south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 3m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be around 580mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 4.79 mAOD, this is 0.6 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
Storm Agnes is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely overnight on 27/09/2023 between 10:30 PM and 11:30 PM.
No property flooding is expected.
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. The following tide tomorrow morning is not forecast to trigger any alerts and as such it is expected that this alert will be removed.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 28/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The weather forecast this morning, 27 September 2023, is mostly dry, with some light rainfall possible this afternoon. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
